assessment.title: Chapter 05: Advertising, Integrated Brand Promotion, and Consumer Behavior

item.title: 001: Consumer behavior can be viewed as a process that begins with recognition of a need.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Consumer behavior can be viewed as a process that begins with recognition of a need.
True
False

item.title: 002: The consumption process is based on the sequence of two stages: need recognition and postpurchase use and evaluation.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: The consumption process is based on the sequence of two stages: need recognition and postpurchase use and evaluation.
True
False

item.title: 003: One perspective of consumer behavior is that the consumer is a decision maker.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: One perspective of consumer behavior is that the consumer is a decision maker.
True
False

item.title: 004: An internal search for information is at times sufficient, so there is no need then for an external search for consumers to find what they want.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: An internal search for information is at times sufficient, so there is no need then for an external search for consumers to find what they want.
True
False

item.title: 005: Advertising can influence internal but not external searches.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Advertising can influence internal but not external searches.
True
False

item.title: 006: Evaluative criteria are different for each product category, and consumers each have their own evoked sets generally.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Evaluative criteria are different for each product category, and consumers each have their own evoked sets generally.
True
False

item.title: 007: Melissa is considering sunglasses from Louis Vuitton, Chanel, or Hermes. This represents her evoked set.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Melissa is considering sunglasses from Louis Vuitton, Chanel, or Hermes. This represents her evoked set.
True
False

item.title: 008: Advertisers sometimes try to change a low-involvement choice into one that is high-involvement.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Advertisers sometimes try to change a low-involvement choice into one that is high-involvement.
True
False

item.title: 009: While purchases based on habit are consumption simplifiers, purchases based on brand loyalty are the result of a strong commitment to a brand.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: While purchases based on habit are consumption simplifiers, purchases based on brand loyalty are the result of a strong commitment to a brand.
True
False

item.title: 010: Experience and involvement are both low in the extended problem-solving decision-making mode.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Experience and involvement are both low in the extended problem-solving decision-making mode.
True
False

item.title: 011: When consumers find a particular consumption setting very involving but lack experience in it, they are likely to engage in extended problem solving.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: When consumers find a particular consumption setting very involving but lack experience in it, they are likely to engage in extended problem solving.
True
False

item.title: 012: Jerome always buys Coke and only Coke—not Pepsi or any other cola brand. Consumers like Jerome, who always purchase the same brand to fulfill a need, are demonstrating brand loyalty.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext:
Jerome always buys Coke and only Coke—not Pepsi or any other cola brand. Consumers like Jerome, who always purchase the same brand to fulfill a need, are demonstrating brand loyalty. 

​
True
False

item.title: 013: While grocery shopping, Kate picks up &amp;quot;Krispy’s&amp;quot; cereal instead of the usual cereal that she buys every week. This is an example of variety seeking.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext:
While grocery shopping, Kate picks up "Krispy’s" cereal instead of the usual cereal that she buys every week.

This is an example of variety seeking.
True
False

item.title: 014: When consumers believe a brand to be more popular than it actually is, it is called an accessibility bonus.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: When consumers believe a brand to be more popular than it actually is, it is called an accessibility bonus.
True
False

item.title: 015: Without customer attention, there is a very strong chance that an advertiser’s message will have the anticipated impact.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Without customer attention, there is a very strong chance that an advertiser’s message will have the anticipated impact.
True
False

item.title: 016: Viewing consumers as social beings allows advertisers to consider meanings that consumers associate with brands.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: Viewing consumers as social beings allows advertisers to consider meanings that consumers associate with brands.
True
False

item.title: 017: Advertisements that are consistent with the values of people, a society, or a culture are more likely to stand out, demand attention, and be remembered and accepted.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: Advertisements that are consistent with the values of people, a society, or a culture are more likely to stand out, demand attention, and be remembered and accepted.
True
False

item.title: 018: Consumers participate in rituals.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: Consumers participate in rituals.
True
False

item.title: 019: Social class, race, and ethnicity are ways in which members of a culture are classified by systematic inequalities that affect their social standing; this is known as episodic memory.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: Social class, race, and ethnicity are ways in which members of a culture are classified by systematic inequalities that affect their social standing; this is known as episodic memory.
True
False

item.title: 020: Emotion is irrelevant to advertising.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Emotion is irrelevant to advertising.
True
False

item.title: 021: Brands flourish when the prices and profit margins of brands get very low, and they develop into commodities that are sold based on price.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: Brands flourish when the prices and profit margins of brands get very low, and they develop into commodities that are sold based on price.
True
False

item.title: 022: If social class impacts consumption based on taste, media preferences are likely impacted.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: If social class impacts consumption based on taste, media preferences are likely impacted.
True
False

item.title: 023: Consumer preferences relate with taste.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being
DISC: International Perspective||DISC: International Perspective||OH||United States

material.mattext: Consumer preferences relate with taste.
True
False

item.title: 024: The relationship social stratification has with cultural capital becomes obvious when a person moves between social strata.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: The relationship social stratification has with cultural capital becomes obvious when a person moves between social strata.
True
False

item.title: 025: Doritos partnered with the LGTBQ+ community in order to both promote understanding and promote its brand.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: Doritos partnered with the LGTBQ+ community in order to both promote understanding and promote its brand.
True
False

item.title: 026: Stratification is the existence of systematic inequalities in things such as income, wealth, status, power, and education.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States
DISC: International Perspective||DISC: International Perspective||OH||United States

material.mattext: Stratification is the existence of systematic inequalities in things such as income, wealth, status, power, and education.
True
False

item.title: 027: Advertisers are very interested in how families behave as consumers.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: Advertisers are very interested in how families behave as consumers.
True
False

item.title: 028: Two bases in consumer behavior are:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Two bases in consumer behavior are:
psychological and social.
formal and informal.
predictable and non-predictable.
accounting and real estate.

item.title: 029: Need recognition, information search and alternative evaluation, purchase, and postpurchase use and evaluation represent the four stages of the:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Need recognition, information search and alternative evaluation, purchase, and postpurchase use and evaluation represent the four stages of the:
creation of brands.
integrated brand promotion process.
consumer decision-making process.
cultural branding method.

item.title: 030: What arises when the actual situation is different from what a consumer desires?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: What arises when the actual situation is different form what the consumer desires?
An evoked set
A need state
A consideration set
Top-of-mind awareness

item.title: 031: Maria goes to pour her morning cup of juice. However, she realizes that she&apos;s run out, which leaves her feeling discontent and wanting juice. This example relates with:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext: Maria goes to pour her morning cup of juice. However, she realizes that she's run out, which leaves her feeling discontent and wanting juice. This example relates with:
a need state
cognitive dissonance
an evoked set
stratification

item.title: 032: Which of the following may involve tapping into information that has amassed in one&apos;s memory from repeated exposure to advertising?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Which of the following may involve tapping into information that has amassed in one's memory from repeated exposure to advertising?
Involvement
Stratification
An internal search
A life-stage variable

item.title: 033: A young man tends to buy things that allow him to experience pleasure, avoid guilt, feel pride, or relieve fear. In doing so, he chooses products based on:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: A young man tends to buy things that allow him to experience pleasure, avoid guilt, feel pride, or relieve fear. In doing so, he chooses products based on:
emotional benefits.
rituals.
cognitive dissonance.
life-stage variables.

item.title: 034: Once consumers decide that they need something, what is the first step they take as they begin to think about a product purchase?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Once consumers decide that they need something, what is the first step they take as they begin to think about a product purchase?
Use an external search process.
Conduct an internal search for information.
Use an alternative evaluation process.
Determine the degree of cognitive dissonance.

item.title: 035: The set of brands that one immediately thinks of when a product category is mentioned is referred to as:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: The set of brands that one immediately thinks of when a product category is mentioned is referred to as:
an external search.
conversion.
cognitive dissonance.
an evoked set.

item.title: 036: Carol needs a new car. Before doing any research, she immediately considers buying a Honda, Ford, Kia, or Subaru; this is her:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext: Carol needs a new car. Before doing any research, she immediately considers buying a Honda, Ford, Kia, or Subaru; this is her:
external search.
need state.
evoked set.
stratification.

item.title: 037: An advertisement for a smartphone contains detailed copy, technical information, and a long list of product design features. In general, this ad would be most appropriate for someone who is:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext: An advertisement for a smartphone contains detailed copy, technical information, and a long list of product design features. In general, this ad would be most appropriate for someone who is:
conducting an external search.
easily influenced by subliminal advertising.
experiencing advertising clutter.
trying to fulfill a basic need.

item.title: 038: Which of the following statements would be made by someone experiencing cognitive dissonance?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext: Which of the following statements would be made by someone experiencing cognitive dissonance?
“I sure need a new lawn mower, but I'm too lazy to find out what's out there.”
“I’d like to buy one of those new Toro lawn mowers, but they’re kind of expensive.”
“I hear the new Toro lawn mowers are one of the best on the market, but my neighbor says his is hard to start.”
“I've bought a Toro lawn mower, but I now realize the new John Deere might have been a better choice.”

item.title: 039: The concept of cognitive dissonance is more commonly referred to as:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: The concept of cognitive dissonance is more commonly referred to as:
advertising clutter.
buyer’s remorse.
variety seeking.
a need state.

item.title: 040: The idea of involvement in the context of consumer decision-making refers to how:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: The idea of involvement in the context of consumer decision-making refers to how:
a person will use a product or service.
much importance accompanies the choice of a product.
an individual's past experience with a product makes the person more aware about it.
the consumer first heard about a product or brand.

item.title: 041: A person is most likely to have a high degree of involvement while buying:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: A person is most likely to have a high degree of involvement while buying:
laundry detergent.
a notepad.
paper towels.
a car.

item.title: 042: Sofia needs to buy a tent, sleeping bag, and hiking boots for a two-week camping trip in the mountains

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext: Sofia needs to buy a tent, sleeping bag, and hiking boots for a two-week camping trip in the mountains. She has never bought camping equipment before and assesses what other equipment she may require during her trip. She also asks her friends, who have gone camping before, what equipment she should buy. Once she has purchased all the camping gear, she evaluates whether she made the right purchases. In this situation, Sofia is engaging in:
extended problem solving.
top of mind awareness.
stratification.
variety seeking.

item.title: 043: Which of the following modes of consumer decision-making involves low involvement and low experience?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Which of the following modes of consumer decision-making involves low involvement and low experience?
Limited problem solving
Habit or variety seeking
Extended problem solving
Brand loyalty

item.title: 044: A young mother consistently buys Chips Ahoy for a special treat. However, every now and then she buys Keebler Animal Crackers for a change in taste. Which mode of consumer decision making does this demonstrate?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext: A young mother consistently buys Chips Ahoy for a special treat. However, every now and then, she buys Keebler Animal Crackers for a change in taste. Which mode of consumer decision making does this demonstrate?
Clutter
Variety seeking
Cognitive dissonance
Stratification

item.title: 045: Which of the following is a difference between brand loyalty and habit?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Which of the following is a difference between brand loyalty and a habit?
Habit involves low involvement, whereas brand loyalty involves high involvement.
Brand loyalty is not based on emotional connections, whereas habit is based on emotional connections.
Brand loyalty can be easily disrupted with skillful advertisement, whereas habit cannot be disrupted with advertisements.
Unlike brand loyalty, habit is based on a deliberate commitment to always buy this brand when making purchases in this product category.

item.title: 046: Which of the following serves to solve a straightforward consumption problem and occurs in settings where a decision isn’t involved?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Which of the following serves to solve a straightforward consumption problem and occurs in settings where a decision isn’t involved?
Extended problem solving
Habit
Conversion
Brand loyalty

item.title: 047: Which of the following refers to when consumers change information in a positive way to favor a particular brand with which they have an emotional connection?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Which of the following refers to when consumers change information in a positive way to favor a particular brand with which they have an emotional connection?
A need state
Cognitive dissonance
Predecisional distortion
Stratification

item.title: 048: What type of memory is used to retrieve words, names, and concepts from one’s mind?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: What type of memory is used to retrieve words, names, and concepts from one’s mind?
Iconic
Episodic
Emotional
Semantic

item.title: 049: A survey was conducted by Spotless, a dishwashing liquid manufacturer, at a department store.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: A survey was conducted by Spotless, a dishwashing liquid manufacturer, at a department store. During the survey, the store manager asked customers which dishwashing liquid they utilized, to which most of them immediately replied, "Spotless." When asked why, the customers stated that they felt it was used by everyone and was the most popular. Based on the given scenario, it can be said that Spotless has:
low brand loyalty.
high involvement.
an accessibility bonus.
a low economy of scale.

item.title: 050: Which of the following is a similarity between habit and variety seeking?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Which of the following is a similarity between habit and variety seeking?
They refer to the tendency of consumers to continue using a brand for many years.
They both involve a high degree of brand loyalty.
They involve a high degree of emotional connection to a brand.
They occur in settings where a decision is not involved.

item.title: 051: There is a value that cultures place on certain objects. Wes gets a nod among groups for his expensive and rare Porsche, which is admired. This scenario demonstrates the concept of:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States
DISC: Marketing Plan||DISC: Marketing Plan||OH||United States

material.mattext: There is a value that cultures place on certain objects. Wes gets a nod among groups for his expensive and rare Porsche, which is admired. This scenario demonstrates the concept of:
an internal search.
conversion.
cultural capital.
variety seeking.

item.title: 052: Manuel sees so many brands claiming related performance claims and so many ads

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext: Manuel sees so many brands claiming related performance claims and so many ads in general in the product category that he cannot process them all. In this scenario, Manuel is encountering:
cognitive dissonance.
a high degree of brand loyalty.
advertising clutter.
predecisional distortion

item.title: 053: Every evening after dinner, Melinda fixes herself a cup of Sleepytime tea

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: Every evening after dinner, Melinda fixes herself a cup of Sleepytime tea and sips it while writing in her journal about her day. This routine helps her wind down at the end of the day, and she plans to never change it. What is this describing?
A consumer who is not exposed to massive volumes of ads
A consumer who seeks variety
A consumer who is resistant to changing rituals
A consumer who misinterprets messages

item.title: 054: Trendy music, celebrities, and things that are novel or different are all devices for combatting:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext: Trendy music, celebrities, and things that are novel or different are all devices for combatting:
conversion.
limited problem solving.
cognitive dissonance.
selective attention.

item.title: 055: Which of the following is true about branding and advertising based on social and cultural factors?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: Which of the following is true about branding and advertising based on social and cultural factors?
Consumer behavior lacks the ability to be meaningfully social.
Advertisements focus on manipulating attitudes.
Consumers are seen as information processors.
Meaning is an important focus for advertisements.

item.title: 056: Which of the following best describes the social meaning approach?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: Which of the following best describes the social meaning approach?
It focuses on using beliefs and rituals to subconsciously manipulate people into buying something they don't need.
It centers on viewing consumers solely as information processors.
It involves making connections with people in relation to their consumption practices
It refers to connecting with people by using ads as mere socially isolated attempts to influence their attitudes.

item.title: 057: In the world of advertising, culture is seen as:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: In the world of advertising, culture is seen as:
people’s rules and regulations.
the total way of life of a people.
a sense of morality in society.
the spiritual beliefs of people.

item.title: 058: Which of the following is true of culture?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being
DISC: Marketing Plan||DISC: Marketing Plan||OH||United States

material.mattext: Which of the following is true of culture?
It is a continual force that exists in the background.
It is purely national or global.
It is most visible to those who are immersed in it.
It is always geographic.

item.title: 059: A commercial for roses says that it’s not Valentine’s Day unless there are flowers for a gift to women,

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: A commercial for roses says that it’s not Valentine’s Day unless there are flowers for a gift to women, and it’s not a Valentine’s Day dinner without this florist’s roses. This ad attempts to tie the product to a:
social attitude.
purchasing habit.
cultural ritual.
social class.

item.title: 060: A person’s standing in American society is often based on social stratification, which reflects the systematic

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being
DISC: Marketing Plan||DISC: Marketing Plan||OH||United States

material.mattext:
A person’s standing in American society is often based on social stratification, which reflects the systematic

inequalities within that society regarding:
caste and gender.
cultural engagement and emotional intelligence.
wealth, power, education, and status.
religious beliefs, morals, and values.

item.title: 061: Which of the following is one of the things stratification is based on?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being
DISC: Marketing Plan||DISC: Marketing Plan||OH||United States

material.mattext: Which of the following is one of the things stratification is based on?
Political beliefs
Emotional intelligence
Religious beliefs
Income

item.title: 062: One of the main reasons why social class may not be completely reliable in predicting the preferences and tastes of

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: One of the main reasons why social class may not be completely reliable in predicting the preferences and tastes of Americans is that:
it has little to do with demographics.
it has a hierarchical structure and involves assigned membership.
many people with a wide income range call themselves "middle class."
it is static, unchanging, and permanent.

item.title: 063: Related to the way a consumer’s culture shapes his or her tastes and preferences is the concept of cultural capital.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being
DISC: Marketing Plan||DISC: Marketing Plan||OH||United States

material.mattext:
Related to the way a consumer’s culture shapes his or her tastes and preferences is the concept of cultural capital.

This refers to the:
value that a culture gives to specific consumption practices or objects.
particular pattern of consumption that depends on fiscal stability.
financial investment needed to create a brand.
monetary value of a brand in a particular area.

item.title: 064: A designer purse, used by a celebrity, would have:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: A designer purse, used by a celebrity, would have:
high cultural capital.
high social capital.
low inelasticity of demand.
low economies of scale.

item.title: 065: Advertisers understand that once the child or children leave home, the consumption patterns of

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: Advertisers understand that once the child or children leave home, the consumption patterns of the family change. This planning criterion is known as:
cultural capital.
a life-stage variable.
stratification.
accessibility bonus.

item.title: 066: Which of the following is true about gender?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: Which of the following is true about gender?
Advertisers have been reluctant to communicate to men and women in different ways.
Gender is not distributed equally across income.
Advertisers often find gender issues overly sensitive and tend to avoid them.
There are no differences between men and women if they are the products of differential socialization.

item.title: 067: Groups of consumers who feel a unity and a common purpose around a consumer good or service are known as what?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: Groups of consumers who feel a unity and a common purpose around a consumer good or service are known as what?
Brand ambassadors
Trend setters
Trade channels
Brand communities

item.title: 068: Advertisements—just like books, movies, posters, and paintings—can act as sociocultural &amp;quot;texts&amp;quot; that are read and&amp;#160;interpreted by consumers. In this case, advertising:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext: Advertisements—just like books, movies, posters, and paintings—can act as sociocultural “texts” that are read and interpreted by consumers. In this case, advertising:
is an entity separate from mass media.
relies largely on words rather than images.
helps to transmit meaning within a culture.
lacks giving products a social meaning.

item.title: 069: Effective ads turn mere products into actual brands by:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: DISC: International Perspective||DISC: International Perspective||OH||United States

material.mattext: Effective ads turn mere products into actual brands by:
giving them cultural meaning.
keeping prices lower than those of competitors.
offering discounts and sales.
repeating the message in more than one medium.

item.title: 070: Ads become part of our everyday language, landscape, and reality as a result of many people:

material.mattext: Ads become part of our everyday language, landscape, and reality as a result of many people:
being subjected to taste.
being somewhat involved in purchasing decisions.
picking up and adopting their ideas, phrases, agendas, and slogans.
buying certain, selective products based on chance.

item.title: 071: (Scenario 5-1) Gap&apos;s logo had been extremely popular,

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-1

As clothing and accessories retailer Gap, Inc. attempted to carry its brand to greater heights, executives felt that a great way to refresh the company’s logo would be to change it all together. However, perhaps even quicker than the initial decision to change the logo, the masses reacted so negatively to the change that the company went back on its decision. A number of consumers stated that the new logo looked “cheap, like a crummy PowerPoint presentation,” and that was all company executives needed to hear. Gap admitted that the idea of changing the company’s logo was probably not the right move, nor was it the right time to do so. The company will look for other ways to develop the brand. Clearly, Gap’s reaction to consumer sentiments serves as proof that the company cares a great deal about consumer thoughts and opinions.
(Scenario 5-1) Gap's logo had been extremely popular, and most of its customers had sought out and used Gap products for years. This is an example of:
brand loyalty.
variety seeking.
advertising clutter.
cognitive dissonance.

item.title: 072: (Scenario 5-1) Gap’s loyal customers generally believed the company’s products

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-1

As clothing and accessories retailer Gap, Inc. attempted to carry its brand to greater heights, executives felt that a great way to refresh the company’s logo would be to change it all together. However, perhaps even quicker than the initial decision to change the logo, the masses reacted so negatively to the change that the company went back on its decision. A number of consumers stated that the new logo looked “cheap, like a crummy PowerPoint presentation,” and that was all company executives needed to hear. Gap admitted that the idea of changing the company’s logo was probably not the right move, nor was it the right time to do so. The company will look for other ways to develop the brand. Clearly, Gap’s reaction to consumer sentiments serves as proof that the company cares a great deal about consumer thoughts and opinions.

(Scenario 5-1) Gap’s loyal customers generally believed the company’s products were high-end and sophisticated. Judging by the initial responses, consumers felt Gap’s new logo represented low-end products, and would, therefore, appeal to a lower social class. This concept of differing social levels is called:
cognitive dissonance.
advertising clutter.
stratification.
cultural capital.

item.title: 073: Scenario 5-1) Facebook played an important role in Gap reversing its decision to change

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext: (Scenario 5-1) Facebook played an important role in Gap reversing its decision to change the company logo. Thousands of users posted status updates expressing their distaste for the new logo, and company executives could not overlook the opinions of their customers. In this situation, Gap had a strong:
need state.
brand community.
internal search.
reaction to advertising clutter.

item.title: 074: (Scenario 5-2) Originally, one reason that the iPhone outsold other smartphones

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-2

Since its introduction to the market in 2007, Apple Inc.’s iPhone dominated other smartphones in terms of units activated per year. However, several years later, Apple began facing stiff competition from Google’s Android software and Samsung. The problem for Apple was that its competition, primarily phones powered by Android operating systems, largely outnumbered the iPhone in terms of available options. In the U.S. alone, there were over twenty smartphone brands that ran on the Android operating system, compared to Apple’s one iPhone. Now more than ever, Apple, which insists on tight control of its devices, must find a way to win in an intensely competitive market against rivals that are openly licensing their software to scores of companies.
(Scenario 5-2) Originally, one reason that the iPhone outsold other smartphones was the feeling of pride many consumers associated with owning one. This represents:
an emotional benefit.
a functional benefit.
a taste state.
cognitive dissonance.

item.title: 075: (Scenario 5-2) While deciding on what brand of cell phone he should buy,

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-2

Since its introduction to the market in 2007, Apple Inc.’s iPhone dominated other smartphones in terms of units activated per year. However, several years later, Apple began facing stiff competition from Google’s Android software and Samsung. The problem for Apple was that its competition, primarily phones powered by Android operating systems, largely outnumbered the iPhone in terms of available options. In the U.S. alone, there were over twenty smartphone brands that ran on the Android operating system, compared to Apple’s one iPhone. Now more than ever, Apple, which insists on tight control of its devices, must find a way to win in an intensely competitive market against rivals that are openly licensing their software to scores of companies.

(Scenario 5-2) While deciding on what brand of cell phone he should buy, Mark, a university student, asks his friend for suggestions on different models of cell phones. His friend immediately says that Apple, Samsung, and Google are good options. This is an example of:
a need state.
stratification.
an evoked set.
cognitive dissonance.

item.title: 076: (Scenario 5-2) Apple has increased its advertising but so have its competitors.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-2

Since its introduction to the market in 2007, Apple Inc.’s iPhone dominated other smartphones in terms of units activated per year. However, several years later, Apple began facing stiff competition from Google’s Android software and Samsung. The problem for Apple was that its competition, primarily phones powered by Android operating systems, largely outnumbered the iPhone in terms of available options. In the U.S. alone, there were over twenty smartphone brands that ran on the Android operating system, compared to Apple’s one iPhone. Now more than ever, Apple, which insists on tight control of its devices, must find a way to win in an intensely competitive market against rivals that are openly licensing their software to scores of companies.

(Scenario 5-2) Apple has increased its advertising but so have its competitors. While searching for a phone with the best camera, Rosie finds seven different advertisements stating that their phones have great camera features when compared to others. Rosie is now confused about which brand to choose. This is an example of:
advertising clutter.
stratification.
predecisional distortion.
life-stage variables.

item.title: 077: (Scenario 5-2) After purchasing a phone, Kathy states that she should have purchased an iPhone rather

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-2

Since its introduction to the market in 2007, Apple Inc.’s iPhone dominated other smartphones in terms of units activated per year. However, several years later, Apple began facing stiff competition from Google’s Android software and Samsung. The problem for Apple was that its competition, primarily phones powered by Android operating systems, largely outnumbered the iPhone in terms of available options. In the U.S. alone, there were over twenty smartphone brands that ran on the Android operating system, compared to Apple’s one iPhone. Now more than ever, Apple, which insists on tight control of its devices, must find a way to win in an intensely competitive market against rivals that are openly licensing their software to scores of companies.
(Scenario 5-2) After purchasing a phone, Kathy states that she should have purchased an iPhone rather than the one she purchased because the iPhone is more popular and elegant. This is an example of:
predecisional distortion.
life-stage variables.
cognitive dissonance.
a need state.

item.title: 078: (Scenario 5-3) When Tina finds out that Kraft cheese is not available,

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-3

While grocery shopping, Tina selects items that she regularly buys because she knows they taste good and she has used them for years. However, the usual Kraft cheese that she buys is not available, so she buys a similar brand of cheese that she hasn't tried but has heard of before. Kraft cheese, being a popular brand, has managed to make itself known, and when most of the customers shopping at the store were asked which cheese they bought, most of them stated Kraft almost immediately.

(Scenario 5-3) When Tina finds out that Kraft cheese is not available, she buys another brand of cheese. As cheese isn't the most important item on her list, she spends very little time picking an alternate brand of cheese. This is an example of:
extended problem solving.
limited problem solving.
stratification.
electronic word-of-mouth.

item.title: 079: (Scenario 5-3) The management had asked all store managers to ask t

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-3

While grocery shopping, Tina selects items that she regularly buys because she knows they taste good and she has used them for years. However, the usual Kraft cheese that she buys is not available, so she buys a similar brand of cheese that she hasn't tried but has heard of before. Kraft cheese, being a popular brand, has managed to make itself known, and when most of the customers shopping at the store were asked which cheese they bought, most of them stated Kraft almost immediately.

(Scenario 5-3) The management had asked all store managers to ask their customers which cheese they preferred and thought was popular. When customers were asked this question, they quickly said Kraft because they thought it had a huge market share. Kraft cheese has created a(n):
accessibility bonus.
external search.
process of variety seeking.
cognitive dissonance.

item.title: 080: (Scenario 5-3) When Tina saw that the cheese she wanted was out of stock,

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-3

While grocery shopping, Tina selects items that she regularly buys because she knows they taste good and she has used them for years. However, the usual Kraft cheese that she buys is not available, so she buys a similar brand of cheese that she hasn't tried but has heard of before. Kraft cheese, being a popular brand, has managed to make itself known, and when most of the customers shopping at the store were asked which cheese they bought, most of them stated Kraft almost immediately.
(Scenario 5-3) When Tina saw that the cheese she wanted was out of stock, she compared the labels on the Porky's, Cubby Cow's, and DairyDelight cheeses before choosing one. This is an example of:
an external search.
an internal search.
an evoked set.
conversion.

item.title: 081: Scenario 5-3) Kraft cheese tries to get its customers to buy its cheese more than once. This is known as:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-3

While grocery shopping, Tina selects items that she regularly buys because she knows they taste good and she has used them for years. However, the usual Kraft cheese that she buys is not available, so she buys a similar brand of cheese that she hasn't tried but has heard of before. Kraft cheese, being a popular brand, has managed to make itself known, and when most of the customers shopping at the store were asked which cheese they bought, most of them stated Kraft almost immediately.
(Scenario 5-3) Kraft cheese tries to get its customers to buy its cheese more than once. This is known as:
habit.
low involvement.
conversion.
an accessibility bonus.

item.title: 082: (Scenario 5-4) Sing advertises its slogan in a way that people will immediately associate it with its motorcycles. Sing is using advertising which involves the:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-4

Sing, a motorcycle manufacturer, aims to make its slogan "Sing Motorcycling" known to every individual in a way that they immediately associate it with the firm. The company has created a social media page where almost a thousand fans have registered. However, there are two competitors who advertise the same features. Sing has a large number of customers who think Sing’s motorcycles are the best and no other make is better.
(Scenario 5-4) Sing advertises its slogan in a way that people will immediately associate it with its motorcycles. Sing is using advertising which involves the:
episodic memory.
emotional memory.
iconic memory.
semantic memory.

item.title: 083: (Scenario 5-4) A lot of fans have joined Sing’s social media page. This is an example of:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-4

Sing, a motorcycle manufacturer, aims to make its slogan "Sing Motorcycling" known to every individual in a way that they immediately associate it with the firm. The company has created a social media page where almost a thousand fans have registered. However, there are two competitors who advertise the same features. Sing has a large number of customers who think Sing’s motorcycles are the best and no other make is better.
(Scenario 5-4) A lot of fans have joined Sing’s social media page. This is an example of:
a life-stage variable.
variety seeking.
a brand community.
advertising clutter.

item.title: 084: (Scenario 5-4) Tony is about to buy a limited edition motorcycle from Sing. It is most likely that Tony is what type of consumer, since this will be his family’s third purchase from Sing?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-4

Sing, a motorcycle manufacturer, aims to make its slogan "Sing Motorcycling" known to every individual in a way that they immediately associate it with the firm. The company has created a social media page where almost a thousand fans have registered. However, there are two competitors who advertise the same features. Sing has a large number of customers who think Sing’s motorcycles are the best and no other make is better.
(Scenario 5-4) Tony is about to buy a limited edition motorcycle from Sing. It is most likely that Tony is what type of consumer, since this will be his family’s third purchase from Sing?
Habitual
High involvement
Variety seeking
Limited problem solving

item.title: 085: (Scenario 5-4) The people of Sing believe that if a person drives a motorcycle, that means the person can afford a lifestyle of getaways and the most expensive motorcycle on the market. It is most likely that owning a motorcycle by Sing would have:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-4

Sing, a motorcycle manufacturer, aims to make its slogan "Sing Motorcycling" known to every individual in a way that they immediately associate it with the firm. The company has created a social media page where almost a thousand fans have registered. However, there are two competitors who advertise the same features. Sing has a large number of customers who think Sing’s motorcycles are the best and no other make is better.

(Scenario 5-4) The people of Sing believe that if a person drives a motorcycle, that means the person can afford a lifestyle of getaways and the most expensive motorcycle on the market. It is most likely that owning a motorcycle by Sing would have:
high cultural capital.
inequality of demand.
low economies of scale.
low involvement.

item.title: 086: (Scenario 5-4) Part of Sing’s goal is to be the first brand consumers automatically think of whenever they think about motorcycles. Sing is seeking what?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-4

Sing, a motorcycle manufacturer, aims to make its slogan "Sing Motorcycling" known to every individual in a way that they immediately associate it with the firm. The company has created a social media page where almost a thousand fans have registered. However, there are two competitors who advertise the same features. Sing has a large number of customers who think Sing’s motorcycles are the best and no other make is better.
(Scenario 5-4) Part of Sing’s goal is to be the first brand consumers automatically think of whenever they think about motorcycles. Sing is seeking what?
Top of mind awareness
Brand loyalty
Predecisional distortion
Habitual purchasing

item.title: 087: (Scenario 5-4) Sing has a large number of people who think that they have the best motorcycles in the industry. They think of them whenever they want to buy one. This is an example of:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext: (Scenario 5-4) Sing has a large number of people who think that they have the best motorcycles in the industry. They think of them whenever they want to buy one. This is an example of:
brand loyalty.
cognitive dissonance.
variety seeking.
stratification.

item.title: 088: (Scenario 5-5) The consumption process for the grill began when Ben:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-5

Ben was preparing to host a graduation party for his friends and relatives when he suddenly realized that he did not have a grill for the barbeque his friends wanted. Having never purchased a grill before, he felt that he needed to shop carefully and take his friends' suggestions on which brand to buy. After visiting several stores and examining numerous models and brands, he settled on a Grillmate model that cost $240.
(Scenario 5-5) The consumption process for the grill began when Ben:
brought home a grill from the store.
identified the criteria he would use to look for grills.
made a mental list of the brands he would consider.
realized he did not have a grill for the party.

item.title: 089: (Scenario 5-5) Ben realized that he did not have a grill for the party. This is an example of:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-5

Ben was preparing to host a graduation party for his friends and relatives when he suddenly realized that he did not have a grill for the barbeque his friends wanted. Having never purchased a grill before, he felt that he needed to shop carefully and take his friends' suggestions on which brand to buy. After visiting several stores and examining numerous models and brands, he settled on a Grillmate model that cost $240.
(Scenario 5-5) Ben realized that he did not have a grill for the party. This is an example of:
an information search.
an alternative evaluation.
cognitive dissonance.
a need state.

item.title: 090: (Scenario 5-5) Ben asked his friends for suggestions on which brand of grill he should purchase. This is an example of:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-5

Ben was preparing to host a graduation party for his friends and relatives when he suddenly realized that he did not have a grill for the barbeque his friends wanted. Having never purchased a grill before, he felt that he needed to shop carefully and take his friends' suggestions on which brand to buy. After visiting several stores and examining numerous models and brands, he settled on a Grillmate model that cost $240.
(Scenario 5-5) Ben asked his friends for suggestions on which brand of grill he should purchase. This is an example of:
need recognition.
postpurchase use.
top of mind awareness.
information search.

item.title: 091: (Scenario 5-5) Which of the following best describes Ben’s mode of consumer decision making in buying a grill?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-5

Ben was preparing to host a graduation party for his friends and relatives when he suddenly realized that he did not have a grill for the barbeque his friends wanted. Having never purchased a grill before, he felt that he needed to shop carefully and take his friends' suggestions on which brand to buy. After visiting several stores and examining numerous models and brands, he settled on a Grillmate model that cost $240.
(Scenario 5-5) Which of the following best describes Ben’s mode of consumer decision making in buying a grill?
Limited problem solving
Low involvement
Extended problem solving
Predecisional distortion

item.title: 092: (Scenario 5-5) Ben mentions to another shopper at the store that low-quality grills are made with cheaper looking parts and high-quality grills have better looking parts. This comment represents Ben’s:

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-5

Ben was preparing to host a graduation party for his friends and relatives when he suddenly realized that he did not have a grill for the barbeque his friends wanted. Having never purchased a grill before, he felt that he needed to shop carefully and take his friends' suggestions on which brand to buy. After visiting several stores and examining numerous models and brands, he settled on a Grillmate model that cost $240.

(Scenario 5-5) Ben mentions to another shopper at the store that low-quality grills are made with more cheap looking parts and high-quality grills have better looking parts. This comment represents Ben’s:
taste.
brand loyalty.
brand attitude.
habits.

item.title: 093: (Scenario 5-6) Of these brands, which one has achieved top-of-mind awareness for Kiara?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-6

Kiara’s freezer doesn’t seem to be staying as cold as it should, and she wants to buy a new one before it completely stops working. The first brand she thinks of is Frigidaire. Other brands that come to mind are GE, LG, and Samsung. She asks her friends for suggestions. Two of them have Whirlpools, one has a Bosch, and one has a KitchenAid. She now has seven brands that she wants to look into.
(Scenario 5-6) Of these brands, which one has achieved top-of-mind awareness for Kiara?
GE
Frigidaire
LG
Whirlpool

item.title: 094: (Scenario 5-6) Which brands are in Kiara’s evoked set?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-6

Kiara’s freezer doesn’t seem to be staying as cold as it should, and she wants to buy a new one before it completely stops working. The first brand she thinks of is Frigidaire. Other brands that come to mind are GE, LG, and Samsung. She asks her friends for suggestions. Two of them have Whirlpools, one has a Bosch, and one has a KitchenAid. She now has seven brands that she wants to look into.
(Scenario 5-6) Which brands are in Kiara’s evoked set?
Whirlpool, Bosch, and KitchenAid
Whirlpool and Frigidaire
Frigidaire, GE, LG, Samsung, Whirlpool, Bosch, and KitchenAid
Frigidaire, GE, LG and Samsung

item.title: 095: (Scenario 5-6) All seven brands make up what?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-6

Kiara’s freezer doesn’t seem to be staying as cold as it should, and she wants to buy a new one before it completely stops working. The first brand she thinks of is Frigidaire. Other brands that come to mind are GE, LG, and Samsung. She asks her friends for suggestions. Two of them have Whirlpools, one has a Bosch, and one has a KitchenAid. She now has seven brands that she wants to look into.
(Scenario 5-6) All seven brands make up what?
Consideration set
Predecisional distortion
Decision set
Postpurchase distortion

item.title: 096: (Scenario 5-6) The advertisements Kiara saw for a KitchenAid showed it in a kitchen in which friends or family were gathered, talking and laughing warmly as they took traditional food for a holiday meal out of the refrigerator and

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-6

Kiara’s freezer doesn’t seem to be staying as cold as it should, and she wants to buy a new one before it completely stops working. The first brand she thinks of is Frigidaire. Other brands that come to mind are GE, LG, and Samsung. She asks her friends for suggestions. Two of them have Whirlpools, one has a Bosch, and one has a KitchenAid. She now has seven brands that she wants to look into.

(Scenario 5-6) The advertisements Kiara saw for a KitchenAid showed it in a kitchen in which friends or family were gathered, talking and laughing warmly as they took traditional food for a holiday meal out of the refrigerator and arranged it on the kitchen counter. This ad is appealing to what?
Cultural rituals
Brand loyalty
Brand community
Social status

item.title: 097: (Scenario 5-6) One of the friends Kiara spoke to told her the brand refrigerator he owned but also said that he did not like it for a number of reasons. He told Kiara not to buy that brand. This friend is experiencing what?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker
BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||BUSPROG: Reflective Thinking||United States

material.mattext:
Scenario 5-6

Kiara’s freezer doesn’t seem to be staying as cold as it should, and she wants to buy a new one before it completely stops working. The first brand she thinks of is Frigidaire. Other brands that come to mind are GE, LG, and Samsung. She asks her friends for suggestions. Two of them have Whirlpools, one has a Bosch, and one has a KitchenAid. She now has seven brands that she wants to look into.

(Scenario 5-6) One of the friends Kiara spoke to told her the brand refrigerator he owned but also said that he did not like it for a number of reasons. He told Kiara not to buy that brand. This friend is experiencing what?
Variety seeking
Brand loyalty
Cognitive dissonance
Stratification

item.title: 098: Which of the following is most likely a function of the consumer-brand relationship?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Which of the following is most likely a function of the consumer-brand relationship?
Higher involvement
Lower involvement
Higher experience
Lower experience

item.title: 099: Advertising clutter refers to what?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Advertising clutter refers to what?
The ability of consumers to retrieve an ad from memory
The context in which consumers view and process ads
The amount of attention a consumer chooses to pay to a specific ad
The relative amount of text and white space in a print advertisement

item.title: 100: Which of the following is a means of moving meaning from the culturally constituted world to consumer goods?

material.mattext: Which of the following is a means of moving meaning from the culturally constituted world to consumer goods?
Possession ritual
Exchange ritual
Fashion system
Divestment

item.title: 101: According to McCracken’s model, the ultimate goal is to move meaning where?

material.mattext: According to McCracken’s model, the ultimate goal is to move meaning where?
To the culturally constituted world
To consumer goods
To the brand community
To the individual consumer

item.title: 102: According to McCracken’s model, which of the following concepts would give a product social meaning?

material.mattext: According to McCracken’s model, which of the following concepts would give a product social meaning?
Present the product in selected slice-of-life scenes
Have a celebrity endorse the product
Provide a list of the features of the product
Highlight the care taken by the workers who built the product

item.title: 103: Why is it often difficult to &amp;quot;get&amp;quot; a foreign film?

material.mattext: Why is it often difficult to “get” a foreign film?
It isn’t presented in the viewer’s native tongue.
Subtitles distract the viewer from the meaning.
The viewer doesn’t understand the cultural code.
The viewer is not willing to work hard to understand it.

item.title: 104: At what point does a consumer convey the meaning that a product has to others?

material.mattext: At what point does a consumer convey the meaning that a product has to others?
When the consumer performs external research.
When the consumer purchases the product.
When the consumer uses the product.
When the consumer experiences buyer’s remorse over the product.

item.title: 105: What assumption do marketers make about social strata?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: What assumption do marketers make about social strata?
Consumers in lower social strata make more impulse buys.
Consumers in all social strata are alike in their views and outlooks.
Consumers in the same social strata consume in similar ways.
Consumers in higher social strata are easier to persuade.

item.title: 106: Which of the following is true of the idea of identity?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: Which of the following is true of the idea of identity?
Identity is assigned to an individual by others.
One’s sense of identity exists apart from one’s relationships with others.
One’s sense of identity, once defined, is stagnant.
Identity exists solely within a social context.

item.title: 107: Which of the following is true regarding gender and consumption?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: Which of the following is true regarding gender and consumption?
Consumption patterns based on gender have been consistent over time.
There is not a comprehensive list of gender differences in consumption.
Consumption can be predicted fairly accurately based upon gender identity.
Advertisements that accurately stereotype based on gender identity achieve increased consumption.

item.title: 108: People who share traditions or rituals and feel a responsibility to each other can be said to be part of what?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: People who share traditions or rituals and feel a responsibility to each other can be said to be part of what?
A community
A family
A social stratum
An ethnic group

item.title: 109: What, specifically, about one’s occupation might help determine one’s social class?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: What, specifically, about one’s occupation might help determine one’s social class?
How good one is at one’s occupation
How many years one has been in the same occupation
The salary the occupation pays
The prestige of the occupation

item.title: 110: Discuss the need recognition state of the consumer decision-making process.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: Discuss the need recognition state of the consumer decision-making process.

A need state arises when one’s desired state of affairs differs from one’s actual state of affairs. Need states are accompanied by a mental discomfort or anxiety that motivates action; the severity of this discomfort can be widely variable depending on the genesis of the need.

 

One way advertising works is to point to and thereby activate needs that will motivate consumers to buy a product or service. A variety of needs can be fulfilled through consumption, and it is reasonable to suggest that consumers’ needs are often sufficiently recognized and motivating to many consumers. Products and services should provide benefits that fulfill consumers’ needs; hence, one of the advertiser’s primary jobs is to make the connection between the two for the consumer.

item.title: 111: What is cognitive dissonance? Discuss how advertisers can prevent dissonance.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: What is cognitive dissonance? Discuss how advertisers can prevent dissonance.

Advertising plays an important role in alleviating the cognitive dissonance that can occur after a purchase. Cognitive dissonance is the anxiety or regret that lingers after a difficult decision, sometimes called “buyer’s remorse.” Often, rejected alternatives have attractive

features that lead people to second-guess their own decisions. If the goal is to generate satisfied customers, this dissonance must be resolved in a way that leads consumers to conclude that they did make the right decision after all. Purchasing high- cost items or

choosing from categories that include many desirable and comparable brands can yield high levels of cognitive dissonance.

 

When dissonance is expected, it makes good sense for the advertiser to reassure buyers with detailed information about its brands. Postpurchase reinforcement programs might involve direct mail, email, or other types of personalized contacts with the customer. This

postpurchase period represents a great opportunity for the advertiser to have the undivided attention of the consumer and to provide information and advice about product use that will increase customer satisfaction.

item.title: 112: How does the extended problem-solving mode of decision making differ from the limited problem-solving mode of decision making?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: How does the extended problem-solving mode of decision making differ from the limited problem-solving mode of decision making?

When consumers are inexperienced in a particular consumption setting, yet find the setting highly involving, they are likely to engage

in extended problem solving. In this mode, consumers go through a deliberate decision-making process that begins with explicit need recognition, proceeds with careful internal and external search, continues through alternative evaluation and purchase, and ends with a lengthy postpurchase evaluation.

 

In contrast, limited problem solving is a more common mode of decision making. In this mode, experience and involvement are both low. A consumer is less systematic in his or her decision making. The consumer has a new problem to solve, but it is not a problem that is interesting or engaging, so the information search is limited to simply trying the first brand encountered.

item.title: 113: Discuss how emotion plays an important role in consumer behavior.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being

material.mattext: Discuss how emotion plays an important role in consumer behavior.

Emotion is incredibly important in consumer behavior. Researchers have shown that if a brand is associated with a positive emotion or feeling, the subsequent information about the brand is actually distorted in favor of the emotion-linked brand and against others. This means that consumers actually change the nature of incoming information to favor this emotional brand connection. It then affects subsequent consumer decisions in favor of the emotion-linked brand. This power favors the use of emotional branding techniques and brand relationship building, including advertising.

item.title: 114: Discuss culture as a major component in consumers&amp;apos; lives.

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-2 Consumer Behavior Perspective Two: The Consumer as a Social Being
DISC: International Perspective||DISC: International Perspective||OH||United States

material.mattext: Discuss culture as a major component in consumers' lives.

Culture surrounds the creation, transmission, reception, and interpretation of ads and brands, just as it touches every aspect of consumption. Culture is what people do and is the way things are done. Cultures may be large and national, or they may be regional or local, or not geographic at all. It’s usually easier to see and note culture when it’s more distant and unfamiliar. Further, members of a culture often find the ways they do things to be perfectly natural and normal. Culture is also said to be nearly invisible to those who are immersed in it.

item.title: 115: Describe5-3 How Ads Transmit Meaning.

material.mattext: Describe how ads transmit meaning.

Advertising can be thought of as a text. It is “read” and interpreted by consumers.

One can think of it as being like other texts: books, movies, posters, paintings, and so on. It is a creative product. In order to understand ads, one has to know something of the cultural code, or they would make no sense.

 

Advertisers place advertised products and a slice of social life in an ad to get the two to intermingle, to become part of the same social scene. In other words, the product is given social meaning by being placed within an ad that represents an idealized

context. This slice of life, of course, is the type of social setting in which potential customers might find, or desire to find, themselves. According to McCracken’s model, meaning has moved from the world to the product (shoes) by virtue of its sharing

space within the frame of the advertisement.

 

When advertisers put things within the frame of an ad, they want the reader of the ad to put them together seamlessly, to take them together as part of each other. When a consumer purchases or otherwise incorporates that good or service into his or her

own life, the meaning is transferred to the individual consumer. Meaning is thus moved from the world to the product (via advertising) to the individual. When the individual uses the product, that person conveys to others the meaning he or she and the advertisement have now given it. Their use incorporates various rituals that facilitate the movement of meaning from the good to consumer.

item.title: 116: What is an evoked set and a consideration set, and why are they important to advertisers and those working in IBP?

qtimetadatafield.fieldentry: 5-1 Consumer Behavior Perspective One: The Consumer as a Decision Maker

material.mattext: What is an evoked set and a consideration set, and why are they important to advertisers and those working in IBP?

An evoked set is the set of brands that immediately comes to mind when a category is mentioned. It is usually highly related to the consideration set, which is the set of the brands the consumer will evaluate for purchase. Advertisers are interested in consumer’s choice sets, so they can identify both who is a potential customer to serve targeted ads to and also who competitors really are, so their ad messages can even parlay against them. And if advertisers can get their brands into the consumer’s evoked set, there is a better chance of it being considered and ultimately purchased.
